title: Function reference
text:
These objects are the building blocks that your application uses to work with important tasks like fetching market data or submitting a trade order.



Contract
Create a contract

title: Function reference
text:
Functions to inspect docstrings.



get_object
Fetch a griffe object.


preview
Print a friendly representation of a griffe object (e.g. function, docstring)

title: preview
text:
preview(ast, max_depth=999, compact=False, as_string=False)
Print a friendly representation of a griffe object (e.g. function, docstring)


>>> from quartodoc import get_object
>>> obj = get_object("quartodoc", "get_object")
>>> preview(obj.docstring.parsed)
 ...
>>> preview(obj)
 ...

title: preview
text:
>>> from quartodoc import get_object
>>> obj = get_object("quartodoc", "get_object")
>>> preview(obj.docstring.parsed)
 ...
>>> preview(obj)
 ...

title: get_object
text:
get_object(path, object_name=None, parser='numpy', load_aliases=True, dynamic=False, loader=None)
Fetch a griffe object.











Name
Type
Description
Default




path
str
An import path to the object. This should have the form path.to.module:object. For example, quartodoc:get_object or quartodoc:MdRenderer.render.
required


object_name
‘str | None’
(Deprecated). A function name.
None


parser
str
A docstring parser to use.
'numpy'


load_aliases

For aliases that were imported from other modules, should we load that module?
True


dynamic

Whether to dynamically import object. Useful if docstring is not hard-coded, but was set on object by running python code.
False






preview: print a user-friendly preview of a griffe object.



>>> get_function("quartodoc", "get_function")
<Function('get_function', ...






Type
Description




dc.Object
abc

title: sb_server
text:
sb_server(input, output, session)
Add up two integer numbers.
This function simply wraps the + operator, and does not do anything interesting, except for illustrating what the docstring of a very simple function looks like.





Name
Type
Description
Default




num1
int
First number to add.
required


num2
int
Second number to add.
required









Type
Description




int
The sum of num1 and num2.






subtract : Subtract one integer from another.



>>> add(2, 2)
4
>>> add(25, 0)
25
>>> add(10, -10)
0
